content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments may be included in income under Section 108 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new subsection treats taxable unpaid child support payments as amounts includible in gross income by reason of the discharge of indebtedness of the taxpayer. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires eligible taxpayers to send a notice to individuals who failed to make child support payments, informing them to include the amount in their gross income. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send the notice if the address is available. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers. The deduction is limited to $10,000 per child for applicable child support payments remaining unpaid at the end of the taxable year. Eligible taxpayers are individuals with adjusted gross income for the taxable year. Eligible taxpayers must have an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000, unpaid child support of $500 or more, and meet identification requirements. Applicable child support payments include fixed periodic payments or expenses for a qualifying child under a support instrument. The term 'qualifying child' refers to a child of an eligible individual for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151. Payments must be delinquent for at least a year to be considered applicable unpaid child support. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under the Social Security Act. Identification requirements include providing child and payer information on the tax return claiming the deduction. Failure to provide payer information voids the deduction unless certified otherwise. Cost-of-living adjustments for tax deductions increase annually. Subsequent payments previously deducted must be included in gross income if paid later. Exceptions apply if the right to receive the payment is assigned to a State. The text discusses the requirements for a support instrument for child support payments and the deduction allowed for unpaid child support payments in the tax code. The amendments made by this section allow for a new subparagraph regarding applicable child support payments. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will be used solely to pay off the US public debt, as specified in appropriation Acts, and cannot be used for any other purpose.
